History of Present Illness:
 Mr. ___ is a ___ male with the past medical
history of  HTN, HLD, chronic atrial fibrillation on apixaban,
obesity, and CHF (previously EF 25% but recovered to 50-55% most
recently) who presents to the ER with dyspnea.  He was admitted
to ___ in ___ for influenza and was discharged home after. 
He stated at that time, he still felt a little weak, but
otherwise well. A few weeks prior to this admission, he stated
that he felt intermittent palpitations as well as "something not
right."  Over the next few weeks, he developed increasing
dyspnea.  This was moderate in severity, worse with exertion on 
a
few blocks, and associated with orthopnea.  These became more
pronounced more in the few days prior to admission.  In 
addition,
he has experienced URI symptoms this past week including cough,
rinorrhea, wheezing, and malaise.  He denies having any known
sick contacts.  He went to see his cardiologist the day prior to
admission where he was noted to have an elevated HR, though the
value is unavailable at this time. He reports receiving IV
Metoprolol and then being sent to urgent care clinic.  There, 
the
ER note said he received Lasix 40mg IV, but he does not think
that this happened and is unsure if he even had an IV at urgent
care.  They subsequently sent him to the ER at ___. 

He does note medication compliance with his Lasix 20mg PO every
other day, though the last few days he did not take it.  He has
not been eating low-salt foods recently, but does not think that
he has gained any weight or developed overall edema. He has been
unable to sleep, so cannot say if he has PND.  He has had some
wheezing, but no chest pain or chest tightness.

Brief Hospital Course:
SUMMARY/ASSESSMENT:Mr. ___ is a ___ male with the past
medical history of  HTN, HLD, chronic atrial fibrillation on
apixaban, obesity, and CHF (previously EF 25% but recovered to
50-55% most recently) who presents to the ER with acute 
hypoxemic
respiratory failure and A fib with RVR.  

# Acute hypoxic respiratory failure
Due to ? exacerbation of underlying COPD and component of 
decompensated heart failure.
He improved well to diuretics and bronchodilators, steroids and 
antibiotics.  He as 238 lbs on discharge, his normal weight is 
between 236-240 lbs.  He will finish a five day course of 
antibiotics, prednisone 40 mg and azithromycin.  He was also 
discharged with albuterol MDI (given spacer and teaching done) 
as well as Spiriva MDI.  He was counseled to have PFTs done as 
an outpatient.  He was hypoxic on arrival to the ED, but this 
had resolved on arrival to the floor, and oxygen saturation was 
95% at rest, he did have desaturations during walking, mostly 
around 88%, but occasionally as low as 86%.  He is not 
interested in home oxygen at this time, preferring to see if his 
oxygenation improves with additional treatment.  Outpatient 
providers should also perform ambulatory saturation.  
He also likely has component of obesity hypoventilation causing 
his hypoxia.  
He has a long standing smoking history.  

# Atrial fibrillation with RVR, Tricuspid regurgitation, HTN,
Hyperlipidemia 
- Cardiologist changed Coreg 12.5mg PO BID which he had on
previous discharge to Toprol XL 100mg PO daily.  This was 
changed
to 200mg PO daily recently which was continued on discharge
- Continue Apixaban, Lisinopril, statin 

#Anemia - mild and secondary to inflammation and phlebotomy -
He is schedule for colonoscopy next week at ___, but he is not 
iron deficient by our labs, nor is he macrocytic.  Anemia may be 
due to myelosuppression due to heavy and long standing drinking 
history.  

#Proteinuria - Urine culture sent in the ER, but for unclear
reasons.  No need for empiric ABX for UTI.  

# Tobacco use disorder - no cigarettes in the past 2 months,
continue nicotine gum 

# Alcohol use disorder - previously drank 6 beers/day, but none
in the past 3 days.  He has no symptoms or signs of withdrawal
(RVR has alternative explanation). He had no scoring on CIWA
previous admission.  He did not exhibit any signs or symptoms of 
alcohol withdrawal.  He endorses drinking less (fewer days of 
the week), is consuming vodka or gin mixed with coke, up to four 
drinks a night.  He endorses drinking due to depression.  I 
advised f/u with his PCP for consideration of acamprosate to 
help curbe drinking, and discussed risk of alcoholic liver 
injury.  On my exam he does not have a palpable liver margin or 
gynecomastia or spider angiomata, but does have some mild palmar 
erythema.  LFTs are within normal limits, albumin pending at 
time of discharge.  

# Hyperglycemia with History of impaired glycemic control: A1c
6.6% in ___ 5.9% in ___.  Carb controlled diet given
prednisone 

# ?History of gout: Patient mentions that for the past several 
years he has intermittently had painful swelling and redness of 
his bilateral great toes and right wrist. Reports previously 
treated for possible cellulitis, but history concerning for 
possible gout, particularly given his history of alcohol use. 

PCP notified of admission 

Greater than ___ hour spent on her care.  
 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Apixaban 5 mg PO BID 
2. Atorvastatin 20 mg PO QPM 
3. Lisinopril 5 mg PO DAILY 
4. nicotine (polacrilex) 2 mg buccal ASDIR 
5. Furosemide 20 mg PO EVERY OTHER DAY 
6. Metoprolol Succinate XL 200 mg PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Albuterol Inhaler 2 PUFF IH TID 
Use your inhaler three times a day until you see your PCP  
2.  Azithromycin 250 mg PO DAILY Duration: 4 Doses 
Take it for 3 more days  
3.  PredniSONE 40 mg PO DAILY 
Take it in the morning for 3 more days  
4.  Tiotropium Bromide 1 CAP IH DAILY  
5.  Apixaban 5 mg PO BID  
6.  Atorvastatin 20 mg PO QPM  
7.  Furosemide 20 mg PO EVERY OTHER DAY  
8.  Lisinopril 5 mg PO DAILY  
9.  Metoprolol Succinate XL 200 mg PO DAILY  
10.  nicotine (polacrilex) 2 mg buccal ASDIR  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
1.  Shortness of breath, low oxygen due to bronchitis, possible 
underlying COPD
2.  Atrial fibrillation
3.  Congestive heart failure
4.  Anemia
5.  Alcohol use

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital with shortness of breath and 
low oxygen levels a week after having some upper respiratory 
(cold) symptoms.  You improved significantly after treatment 
with prednisone, breathing treatments and antibiotics.   I have 
sent your prescriptions to your ___ Pharmacy on ___ in ___.  Please take prednisone 40 mg every morning 
for 3 more days, azithromycin (antibiotic) for three more days.  
 I have prescribed inhalers for you to use at home.  Dr 
___ should obtain pulmonary function tests to 
determine if you have underlying COPD or emphysema.  Also, 
please discuss with her your desire to stop drinking, and to 
discuss whether you might be a candidate for a medication to 
call acamprosate.  
Please avoid alcohol.  It worsens your heart failure and 
increases your chance of developing liver disease.  
 
Followup Instructions:
___

qafib.question: Does the note describe the patient as having permanent, paroxysmal, or persistent afib?

qprior_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having a stroke or transient ischemic attack?

qarterial_hypertension.question: Does the note describe the patient as having arterial hypertension on treatment (high bp e.g. >140, or HTN)?

qt2d.question: Does the note describe the patient as having Diabetes mellitus (DM1, DM2, T2D, T1DM, T2DM)?

qheart_failure.question: Does the note describe the patient as having heart failure?

qsurgical_valvular_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having valvular disease requiring surgery (stenosis)?

qafib_ablation.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a planned or past ablation procedure for afib?

qbleeding.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a serious bleeding in the past 6 months?

qpeptic_ulcer_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having peptic ulcer disease?

qrecent_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a stroke during this admission or within the last month? (Answer yes for any recent stroke if the date is unclear)

qhemorrhagic.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having any hemorrhagic tendencies or blood dyscrasias?

qbipolar.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with bipolar disorder?

qschizophrenia.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with schizophrenia or any schizoaffective disorders?

qmdd.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with depression or major depressive disorder (MDD)?

qmed_decisions.question: Does the note describe the patient as being unable to make medical decisions? (Answer no unless there is evidence the patient cannot make their own medical decisions).

qchads2.question: What is the highest CHADS2 score mentioned? Answer "NA" if no CHADS2 score is in the note.

qblood_glucose.question: What is the highest blood glucose lab mentioned? Answer "NA" if no blood glucose score is in the note.

qlvef.question: What is the lowest left ventricular ejection (LVEF, ef, ejection fraction) fraction mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no LVEF is in the note, Answer 55 if the lowest value is 55% or greater.

qPLT.question: What is the lowest platelet count (PLT) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no platelet count is available in the note.

qHGB.question: What is the lowest hemoglobin (HGB) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no HGB value is available in the note.

qCREAT.question: What is the higest serum creatinine (Creat) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no creatinine value is available in the note.

qAST.question: What is the higest aspartate aminotransferase level (AST) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no AST value is available in the note.

qBILI.question: What is the higest total bilirubin (TotBili, Bili) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no bilirubin value is available in the note.
